articles.content:
Contents of a Wolf Pup‚Äôs Stomach From 14,400 Years Ago Are Teaching Researchers About the Lives of the Last Woolly Rhinos
Analysis of woolly rhinoceros DNA recovered from the permafrost-preserved wolf further hints that the Ice Age beasts went extinct because of a sudden shift in the climate
Roughly 14,400 years ago, a two-month-old wolf pup in what‚Äôs now northern Siberia chowed down on her last meal‚Äîa bit of wagtail, some woolly rhinoceros, a few tufts of arctic bluegrass. Not long after, the young pup and her sister died, possibly because a landslide collapsed on their den. Their bodies were preserved in the permafrost until researchers discovered them in the 21st century.
Now, scientists say they have successfully reconstructed the complete set of genetic instructions, or genome, of the woolly rhinoceros that one of the ‚ÄúTumat puppies‚Äù feasted upon before her untimely death. The ancient rhino DNA‚Äîpreserved inside the wolf pup‚Äôs stomach for millennia‚Äîis revealing fresh insights into how the Ice Age beasts may have gone extinct, researchers report in a study published January 14 in the journal Genome Biology and Evolution.
‚ÄúFor us, many, many, many thousands of years later to have uncovered these beautifully preserved mummified wolf puppies, looked into their stomach contents and found this piece of woolly rhinoceros tissue‚Äîwhich has then shed light on an entirely different species‚Äîis very unique and cool,‚Äù says study co-author Edana Lord, an evolutionary biologist now at the Botanic Gardens of Sydney who conducted the research while at Stockholm University, to New Scientist‚Äôs James Woodford.
Researchers discovered the first wolf pup in 2011 near the present-day settlement of Tumat, Siberia. They unearthed the second in 2015. Both young animals were remarkably well-preserved, with their skin, fur and teeth still intact.
When researchers dissected the pups, they realized their stomachs were also still full of food. The mix contained a chunk of woolly rhinoceros flesh that still had yellowish hair on it.
‚ÄúThe tissue was so intact, it looked like the wolf had just swallowed it before it died,‚Äù says study co-author Camilo Chac√≥n-Duque, an evolutionary geneticist at Uppsala University in Sweden who also conducted the research while at Stockholm University, to National Geographic‚Äôs Jack Tamisea.
Woolly rhinoceroses went extinct just a few centuries after the wolf pups died, but the cause of their demise remains a mystery. Some of the leading theories are climate change, inbreeding and pressure from human hunting. The researchers wondered if the partially digested fragment might offer any clues.
But first, they had to extract the woolly rhinoceros‚Äô DNA‚Äîa highly challenging feat. The team spent months collecting samples from different parts of the fragment, taking care to avoid genetic contamination from the wolf pup. They used a scalpel to cut through the hide, which was dry and tough, similar to a piece of beef jerky, Chac√≥n-Duque tells the New York Times‚Äô Ari Daniel. They sequenced the highest-quality DNA they could extract, then merged the results to cover the entire genome.
They compared this genome with two previously sequenced woolly rhino genomes‚Äîone that was around 18,000 years old and another about 49,000 years old. The more recent woolly rhino that had been eaten by the wolf pups‚Äîa female, their investigation revealed‚Äîshowed no signs of inbreeding or genetic decline compared with the older specimens, which suggests the species was healthy not long before vanishing.
Since the species was nearing extinction at the time, ‚Äúone might assume the last lineages would have small populations and were highly inbred,‚Äù Nathan Wales, an archaeologist at the University of York in England who was not involved with the research, writes in an email to CNN‚Äôs Katie Hunt. ‚ÄúBut this well-established analysis shows that, at a genetic level, the population looked stable.‚Äù
This finding, the researchers argue, further supports the idea that a sudden outside factor, such as a shift in the climate, caused the species to die out. Wales calls this a ‚Äúreasonable conclusion.‚Äù
A few centuries after the woolly rhinos went extinct, the northern hemisphere went through a period of warming known as the B√∏lling‚ÄìAller√∏d interstadial. This changing climate may not have killed off the rhinos directly but, rather, caused changes to their environment that made it impossible for them to survive.
For instance, perhaps warmer temperatures or wetter conditions wiped out the woolly rhinoceroses‚Äô main food source, Laura Epp, an environmental genomicist at the University of Konstanz in Germany who wasn‚Äôt involved in the study, tells the Times. A warmer climate may also have benefitted early humans, so hunting or human-driven habitat loss could also have been factors, Advait Jukar, a vertebrate paleontologist at the Florida Museum of Natural History who also wasn‚Äôt involved in the new research, tells National Geographic.
Another possibility? Some catastrophic event‚Äîlike a natural disaster or a virus‚Äîcould have led to the animals‚Äô demise, which is how the last woolly mammoths may have died.
Did you know? The deaths of the last woolly mammoths
Chac√≥n-Duque and colleagues previously studied how the last woolly mammoths, a population on Wrangel Island northeast of Siberia, died. Although the animals seemed to have low genetic diversity and genetic diseases, the researchers suspect a sudden unlucky incident, such as a novel virus, a volcanic eruption or a tundra fire, ultimately did them in.
Either way, the fate of the woolly rhinoceros might serve as a cautionary tale for conservationists working to protect modern species. The creatures seemed totally fine but still vanished within a few hundred years‚Äîwhich suggests even successful species may only be a few generations away from extinction.
‚ÄúJust because a living species on the surface looks OK genetically doesn‚Äôt mean it‚Äôs not vulnerable,‚Äù says Mick Westbury, an evolutionary biologist at the Technical University of Denmark who was not involved with the research, to NBC News‚Äô Evan Bush.

articles.content:
All Nine of Jan van Eyck‚Äôs Surviving Portraits Are Coming Together for the Very First Time in History
The Northern Renaissance painter‚Äôs innovative techniques altered the course of art history. An upcoming exhibition in London brings together his 15th-century portraits from collections across Europe
On the National Gallery‚Äôs website, the most-visited painting page is devoted to the Arnolfini Portrait. According to the London museum, this painting of a married couple, created by Jan van Eyck in 1434, ‚Äúmust be one of the most famous and intriguing paintings in the world.‚Äù
The figure on the left is likely Giovanni di Nicolao di Arnolfini, an Italian merchant dressed in dark robes and a large hat. On the right is his wife, clothed in a vibrant green gown. The painting‚Äôs details and techniques have stunned critics for centuries. Art historian Ernst Gombrich once called the Arnolfini Portrait ‚Äúa simple corner of the real world ‚Ä¶ fixed on to a panel as if by magic.‚Äù
Born in what‚Äôs now Belgium around the 1390s, van Eyck is known as the father of oil painting. Now, all nine of van Eyck‚Äôs surviving portraits are being united for the first time. ‚ÄúVan Eyck: The Portraits‚Äù will be on view at the National Gallery in London this fall. The collected works make up nearly half of the painter‚Äôs surviving oeuvre.
Fun fact: Shoes in the Arnolfini Portrait
Two pairs of pattens, or overshoes worn on top of flimsy footwear, are visible in this portrait.
‚Äú[Portraiture burst] onto the scene fully formed in the 1430s under the brush of Jan van Eyck,‚Äù says Emma Capron, the museum‚Äôs curator of early Netherlandish and German paintings, in a statement. ‚ÄúNone of the stylized likenesses that preceded his work would pass as a portrait today: You would not recognize their sitters if you walked by them on the street.‚Äù
Before the Renaissance, most artists‚Äô depictions of people weren‚Äôt very lifelike. Instead, they often had exaggerated, flat features. ‚ÄúVan Eyck‚Äôs were the first faces that were genuinely lifelike,‚Äù writes the London Times‚Äô Ed Conway. ‚ÄúThese were not just icons; they were humans. Were the couple from the Arnolfini Portrait, probably his most famous such work, to pass you in the street, you would have no trouble recognizing them.‚Äù
Van Eyck died around 1441, and his only verified portraits that exist today are from the last decade or so of his life. In 1432, van Eyck and his brother, artist Hubert van Eyck, painted the Ghent Altarpiece for St. Bavo‚Äôs Cathedral in Ghent, Belgium. The artwork is sometimes known as ‚Äúthe first major oil painting.‚Äù
‚ÄúVan Eyck is one of the pillars of the National Gallery‚Äôs collection and a foundational figure in the European history of art,‚Äù Gabriele Finaldi, the National Gallery‚Äôs director, says in the statement. ‚ÄúThe portraits reflect a remarkable sensitivity to his sitters and an astounding technical virtuosity in their execution.‚Äù
The portraits on display will include Margaret, the Artist‚Äôs Wife, which dates to 1439 and depicts van Eyck‚Äôs spouse in a red dress and white head covering. Besides this portrait, the museum will display Portrait of a Man (Self-Portrait?), dated to 1433 and thought to depict the artist himself. The piece, which shows a prosperous van Eyck clothed in a ‚Äúflamboyant red hat,‚Äù was recently conserved, per the museum.
The show will also display van Eyck‚Äôs Portrait of a Man (circa 1440) alongside the Arnolfini Portrait, as both are thought to depict the same man. The imported oranges sitting on the windowsill in the double portrait reveal that the Arnolfinis were quite wealthy, as Artnet‚Äôs Jo Lawson-Tancred writes.
Van Eyck‚Äôs realism preceded that of Italy‚Äôs Leonardo da Vinci and Michelangelo, who rose to prominence about half a century after the painter‚Äôs death. Leonardo dissected roughly 30 cadavers to learn more about the human body, aiming to improve the precision of his drawings. Michelangelo also participated in some dissections, which informed his vivid anatomical nudes.
Did van Eyck‚Äôs work also benefit from advances in science and technology? The English painter David Hockney once suggested that van Eyck used newly developed glass lenses to filter and project a scene onto a canvas, which he then traced, per the Times. However, many art historians dispute this theory.
‚ÄúThese portraits‚Äô ability to baffle by their precision and liveliness is intact today,‚Äù Capron says in the statement. ‚ÄúTheir impact belies their intimate scale. We are really proud and grateful to our lenders to be able to show van Eyck‚Äôs pioneering contribution to the rise of portraiture in this once-in-a-lifetime exhibition.‚Äù
‚ÄúVan Eyck: The Portraits‚Äù will be on view at the National Gallery in London from November 21, 2026, to April 11, 2027.

Greenland Sharks Can Survive for Centuries‚Äîand Maintain Long-Lasting Vision, Despite Living in the Dark
The long-living sharks aren‚Äôt as blind as once thought and have DNA repair mechanisms that may help prevent their vision from degrading, a study suggests
Greenland sharks‚Äîthe longest-living vertebrates in the world‚Äîdwell in the deep, frigid waters of the Arctic and North Atlantic for up to roughly 400 years. Scientists have long suspected that the creatures were basically blind due to pesky eye parasites and spending their lengthy lives in such a dimly lit place.
New research has found, however, that the animals seem to have surprisingly good vision and DNA repair mechanisms to maintain it throughout their lifetimes. The findings, published on January 5 in the journal Nature Communications, not only shed light on a long-lasting visual system but could also lead to ways to prevent human sight problems, such as macular degeneration.
Fun fact: Life of a Greenland shark
These marine animals grow slowly, less than half an inch per year, but they can reach lengths of more than 20 feet. They can swim around 10,000 feet below the ocean‚Äôs surface.
Evolutionary biologist Lily Fogg says that the study came about after John Fleng Steffensen, a marine biologist at the University of Copenhagen who recently died, offered her and her colleagues some specimens from his other work. Steffensen previously helped discover the creatures‚Äô centuries-long lifespan via eye samples.
‚ÄúHe said, ‚ÄòI‚Äôve got these eyes, would you like to do a study on them?‚Äô‚Äù Fogg, of the University of Basel in Switzerland, tells Mongabay‚Äôs Bobby Bascomb. ‚ÄúAnd we said, ‚ÄòWhy not? That‚Äôs a great opportunity.‚Äô If they‚Äôre going in the bin, then that would just be a waste.‚Äù
The eyeballs were then sent out to the researchers. ‚ÄúI opened the package, and there was a giant, 200-year-old eyeball sitting on dry ice just staring back at me,‚Äù recalls study co-author Emily Tom, a physiologist at the University of California, Irvine, in a statement.
Overall, the research team examined eyeballs from ten Greenland sharks that were caught off the coast of western Greenland between 2020 and 2024 and ranged in age from about 100 to 134 years old. An analysis revealed no signs of degeneration in the light-sensitive parts of the old organs, and the sharks‚Äô eye parasites didn‚Äôt seem to interfere with the animals‚Äô vision.
Additionally, most vertebrates have two types of light-sensitive eye cells: cones, which differentiate color and work well in bright light, and rods, which don‚Äôt detect colors but work well in dim light. But the Greenland sharks had only rod cells, which means they see in black and white, the team found.
